instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> at 5v
threads.message:
Corrosion was on <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>, <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q8401</TRANSISTOR> and in that area (Possibly under <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> too). And very little corrosion around <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.

I get 5.2 Volts on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
and 0V at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

It doesnt have a short at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

It probabbly is <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> or <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> right ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> at 5v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> at 5v
threads.message: Reflowed U31/200 already? Replace <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> as it can cause this as well. If no change, inject 3.3 volts into <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and see if you get any current draw. If so, figure out what is heating as often one of the CD3215s pulls some current (U31/200). If no current draw, do a diode mode reading around both <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> on the 3v3 1v8 etc LDO rails to see if either chip gives a lower measurement.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> at 5v
threads.message:
Be sure all resistors and traces around <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> are OK.
<CHIP>U2890</CHIP> needs donor board to replace; is USB-C SPI chip (like a BIOS).
Corrosion could break communication between <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>/90.
That is sufficient to get dead board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> at 5v
threads.message: Curious does that chip have to come from a donor?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> at 5v
threads.message: You can use new one, if you are able to flash it with correct dump...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> at 5v
threads.message: I did reflow <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>.. seems not to have improved anything. I dont have Donor board right now, ill get one and replace <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> asap and will let you know

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> at 5v
threads.message: I just noticed, that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> (measured near <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>) is constant 3.3V with the USB-C connected to the first connector. However if i connect it to the second one, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> Spikes to 3.3V and drops gradually untill it hits zero. Then it gets another Spike and repeats that over and over.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> at 5v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> at 5v
threads.message:
You must be sure about all traces of <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>.
The big problem is some trace goes to <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> inside the board.

You may also need to change an USB-C controller (<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> at 5v
threads.message: Yeah did you change what we said to change???
